vignette.presentation:
44. A.49-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 9 months. She has not had vaginal dryness or hot flashes. She has no history of serious

illness or abnormal Pap smears. She has had a levonorgestrel IUD in place for 4 years. Her last visit to a physician was 3 years ago. She is 152 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 Ib);

BMI is 23 kg/m?. Her blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. On pelvic examination, the IUD string cannot be seen at the cervical os.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measurement of serum follicle-stimulating hormone concentration
Pelvic CT scan to localize the IUD

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient presenting with amenorrhea and a possibly displaced IUD is a urine pregnancy test. Amenorrhea may be caused by pregnancy,
menopause or premature ovarian failure, abnormalities or immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, inadequate nutrition, chromosomal abnormalities, and thyroid disorders. The first
step in the evaluation of a premenopausal or perimenopausal patient who presents with amenorrhea is a urine pregnancy test. The other consideration in the diagnosis of this patient's
amenorrhea is the onset of menopause given her age. Menopause is characterized by the lack of ovarian estrogen production, resulting in manifestations such as vaginal atrophy, hot flashes,
and night sweats. Sleep disturbances and mood changes may also be present. However, pregnancy must be ruled out before making the clinical diagnosis of menopause, especially in this
patient with unclear evidence of reliable contraception.
explanation.educational_objective:
Amenorrhea has a variety of causes, including pregnancy and menopause. The first and most important step in the evaluation of a premenopausal or perimenopausal
patient presenting with amenorrhea is a urine pregnancy test, especially in the absence of reliable contraception. Menopause refers to the cessation of menses due to the depletion of ovarian
follicles and is often associated with hot flashes, night sweats, mood changes, sleep disturbances, and vaginal atrophy. If amenorrhea is the only presenting symptom, diagnoses other than
menopause should be thoroughly evaluated.

oO C ro @ € © o

vignette.presentation:
45. A19-year-old man, who is a college freshman, comes to the student health center because of a 2-year history of intermittent headaches that have been occurring more frequently during
the past 6 months and recently have caused him to miss several days of class. He says the headaches affect either the left or right side of his head, and begin with "sparkling lights” in
his peripheral vision and sensitivity to light and sound. The headaches often are brought on by strong odors, hunger, and alcohol consumption. The headaches also are associated with
nausea. The patient says he often tries to "sleep them off." The headaches previously occurred once every few months, but now he has as many as four headaches monthly.
Acetaminophen has provided no relief. He has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination discloses no
abnormalities. Daily use of which of the following medications is most appropriate to recommend to prevent or decrease the frequency of this patient's headaches?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Migraine is a common condition that presents with recurrent primary headaches. Migraines are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and
phonophobia. The pain is usually located behind or adjacent to the eye. Some patients additionally experience an aura before or during the headache, which may present with visual or sensory
symptoms, such as transient vision loss followed by the perception of scintillating shapes or lines and/or paresthesia. Migraine triggers include stress, menstruation, weather changes, fasting,
strong odors, and alcohol. Migraines are postulated to arise from deficient serotonin inhibition of descending pain pathways. Acute migraine treatment includes triptans (eg, serotonin 1B/1D
agonists) and/or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. For patients with disabling or frequent migraines, prophylactic treatment to reduce the frequency of migraine headaches is also
recommended. This includes B-adrenergic blocking drugs such as propranolol or metoprolol, antidepressants (eg, tricyclic antidepressants or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), and
anticonvulsants (eg, topiramate or valproate).
explanation.educational_objective:
Migraines are typically unilateral and pulsating headaches that are associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia, and may also present with visual or
sensory auras. In patients with severe or recurrent migraines, B-adrenergic blocking drugs such as propranolol, antidepressants, and anticonvulsants are commonly used to reduce the frequency
of future migraine headaches. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and triptans are commonly used to abort acute migraine headaches.
oO © @ @ re © o

vignette.presentation:
46. Apreviously healthy 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of acute pain and swelling around the right elbow since sliding into home plate during a baseball

game 30 minutes ago. On arrival, his arm is splinted in newspaper and wrapped with duct tape. He is in acute distress. Examination of the right upper extremity shows edema and severe

tenderness around the elbow. There is a distal right humeral deformity. Radial pulses are decreased on the right. X-rays of the right upper extremity show a transverse fracture of the right

distal humeral metaphysis with posterior displacement of the distal fragment. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following sequelae?

A} Aeute-osteomyelitis

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
In the acute evaluation of extremity fracture, it is important to evaluate for signs of neurovascular compromise distal to the site of injury. The major structures adjacent to the distal humerus
include the ulnar nerve posteriorly near the medial epicondyle, the brachial artery and median nerve in the midline anteriorly, and the radial nerve anterior to the lateral epicondyle. In a midline
transverse fracture of the distal humeral metaphysis, as seen in this patient, the brachial artery and median nerve are at highest risk for compromise. The brachial artery bifurcates into the radial
and ulnar arteries just distal to the elbow joint. In this patient, a brachial artery injury is the most likely sequela because of the finding of a decreased radial pulse. If signs of neurovascular
compromise are observed, emergent reduction and operative fixation is indicated followed by a period of 6 to 8 weeks of immobilization to allow for fracture healing.
explanation.educational_objective:
In acute fractures of the extremity, it is important to evaluate for neurovascular compromise distal to the injury. Symptoms include decreased peripheral pulses, numbness,
tingling, or weakness. The major structures adjacent to the distal humerus include the ulnar nerve posteriorly near the medial epicondyle, the brachial artery, the median nerve in the midline
anteriorly, and the radial nerve anterior to the lateral epicondyle. In this patient, a brachial artery injury is the most likely sequela because of the finding of a decreased radial pulse. When
neurovascular compromise is suspected, emergent surgical evaluation is indicated.

a Cc oO @ @ © ©

vignette.presentation:
2. Examination of the external
genitalia shows no abnormalities. Insertion of a speculum into the vagina is difficult. The cervix cannot be visualized or palpated. The uterus is not palpable.
Karyotype analysis shows a 46,XY chromosome. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A} DNAhybridization- of ehromesome

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Androgen insensitivity syndrome is caused by a defect in the androgen receptor complex resulting in a genetically 46,XY male patient developing a female phenotype.
Testes are present and produce testosterone normally, but the absence of a functioning androgen receptor prevents hormone binding and thereby prevents development of
male sexual characteristics. Patients present with female external genitalia, scant pubic and axillary hair, absent uterus and fallopian tubes, and a rudimentary vagina.
Patients demonstrate increased concentrations of testosterone, estrogen, and luteinizing hormone. Menses will not occur as a result of the lack of cycled progesterone and
estrogen, and the absence of a functional uterus with endometrial lining. The testes of these patients cannot functionally produce sperm, and patients are at high risk for
developing testicular malignancy. For this reason, the next best step in management of this patient is gonadectomy.
explanation.educational_objective:
Androgen insensitivity syndrome is caused by a defect in the androgen receptor and results in patients with 46,XY chromosomes developing
phenotypically female characteristics. Given the significantly increased risk of testicular cancer, gonadectomy should be pursued in patients between age 12 and 18 years
at the onset of puberty or at the time of diagnosis if older than this range.
a C @ © @ 6 om

vignette.presentation:
48. A90-year-old woman, who lives alone, is brought to the emergency department after her family found her lying on the floor of her home. She did not have loss of
consciousness. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On arrival, her pulse is 60/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg.
Examination shows an open fracture of the tibia. Antibiotic therapy is recommended with irrigation, debridement, and surgical stabilization of the tibia with an
intramedullary nail. The patient insists that she will allow irrigation, debridement, and antibiotics but refuses the surgical stabilization and requests discharge to
home as soon as possible. Her family provides documentation that the patient has appointed her son as her durable power of attorney. Which of the following is
the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discuss the situation with the patient's son
Stabilize the fracture with cast immobilization to abide by the patient's wishes

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Elderly or cognitively impaired patients should not be assumed to lack decisional capacity regarding their care on the basis of age or cognitive ability alone. To meet the
criteria for decisional capacity, the patient must express a consistent choice, demonstrate an understanding of the risks and benefits of the choice, demonstrate an
understanding of the significance of the choice for their personal circumstances, and be able to reason through the options. Therefore, to assess this patient's decisional
capacity, the physician should discuss the patient's preferences for care of her fracture and assess the four decisional capacity criteria specific to this decision. If she
possesses decisional capacity, her wishes should be respected. If she does not possess decisional capacity, then the decision should be deferred to her durable power of
attorney. Decisional capacity is specific to each decision as physicians cannot feasibly assess patients’ understanding of every decision. Patients’ global decision-making
ability is referred to as competence and is determined by courts, not physicians.
explanation.educational_objective:
To meet the criteria for decisional capacity, the patient must express a consistent choice, demonstrate an understanding of the risks and benefits of
the choice, demonstrate an understanding of the significance of the choice, and be able to reason through the options. Regardless of a patient's age or cognitive ability, the
physician should assess the patient's decisional capacity for each specific care decision.

vignette.presentation:
49. A21-year-old man comes to the physician for an examination prior to employment. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He

is in his first year of law school and sleeps 4 to 5 hours nightly; he reports feeling stressed frequently because of the demanding course load. He has smoked one

pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years and drinks one beer daily. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 91 kg (200 Ib); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His pulse is 80/min, and blood

pressure is 140/100 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis shows no

abnormalities. In addition to a subsequent blood pressure measurement, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient has mildly elevated blood pressure and several risk factors for hypertension that may be consistent with primary hypertension. Importantly, one isolated
elevated blood pressure reading in an asymptomatic patient does not indicate the patient has hypertension. These elevated pressures need to be confirmed with both in-
office and at-home measurements, or with serial in-office measurements over a period of weeks to months. The primary factors determining blood pressure are renin-
angiotensin-aldosterone system, sympathetic nervous system, and plasma blood volume. Although the exact pathogenesis of primary hypertension is unclear, there are
several risk factors thought to contribute, including advancing age, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, smoking, genetic factors, high-sodium diet, excessive alcoholic beverage
consumption, and insufficient sleep. Left untreated, hypertension can lead to many detrimental long-term effects, including heart failure, ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke,
and chronic kidney disease. If hypertension is confirmed, additional testing should be done to evaluate for end-organ damage, and appropriate treatment (eg, lifestyle
modification, antihypertensive agents) should be discussed with a primary care provider.
explanation.educational_objective:
Risk factors for primary hypertension include advancing age, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, smoking, and excessive alcoholic beverage consumption.
Left untreated, hypertension can lead to many detrimental long-term effects, including heart failure, ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke, and chronic kidney disease. One
isolated elevated blood pressure reading in an asymptomatic patient does not indicate the patient has hypertension. These elevated pressures need to be confirmed with
both in-office and at-home measurements, or with serial in-office measurements over a period of weeks to months prior to a diagnosis.

a C @ @ € © nm

vignette.presentation:
50. An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver. He has shortness of breath and

moderate left-sided chest pain. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination of the chest shows

numerous abrasions and tenderness on the left. Breath sounds are decreased on the left. Heart sounds are normal. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pulse oximetry on

40% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. An x-ray of the chest shows a left pleural effusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in

management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachypnea after a blunt traumatic injury raises concern for rib fracture, pulmonary contusion, pneumothorax, cardiac or pericardial injury, great vessel injury,
and/or hemothorax. Rib fractures can be complicated by injury of the adjacent visceral or parietal pleura or blood vessels, allowing air or blood to collect in between the visceral and parietal
pleura. Hemothorax results from blood accumulating within the pleural space, often from trauma to the pulmonary, bronchial, or intercostal vessels in the setting of rib fractures, blunt, or
penetrating trauma. It presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, dullness to percussion, and diminished breath sounds on the affected side. If massive, hemodynamic instability may occur.
Indicators of massive hemothorax include hemodynamic instability, when greater than 1000-1500 mL of blood is drained with initial insertion of chest tube, or if greater than 200 mL/hr of blood
drains for at least 4 hours. Pulmonary injuries are typically treated supportively with oxygen supplementation and pain control to reduce complications of atelectasis and pneumonia. In the
presence of an associated pneumothorax or hemothorax, tube thoracostomy may be necessary to promote lung expansion, exclude significant hemorrhage, and prevent residual pneumothorax,
empyema, fibrothorax, or fistula. Short-term complications of hemothorax include empyema, atelectasis, superimposed infection, and/or hemorrhagic shock. Given this patient's tachycardia,
tachypnea, and increasing oxygen requirements, tube thoracostomy is the most appropriate next step at this time.
explanation.educational_objective:
Hemothorax results from blood accumulating within the pleural space and can appear on x-ray as fluid accumulation along the diaphragm with blunting of the costophrenic
angle or on CT scan as hyperdense material surrounding the lung between the visceral and parietal pleura. In a patient with tachycardia, tachypnea, and increasing oxygen requirements,
immediate tube thoracostomy is indicated. Complications of hemothorax include empyema, atelectasis, fibrothorax, superimposed infection, and/or hemorrhagic shock.

Section 3

Exam Section 3: Item 1 of 50 National Board of Medical Examiners®
Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Y 4. 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a preoperative examination 2 weeks prior to undergoing a splenectomy. She received the diagnosis of immune thrombocytopenic
y 5 going Vy. aI
purpura 3 months ago. Her platelet count has ranged between 5000/mm; and 20,000/mm; for the past 2 weeks despite treatment with systemic corticosteroids and intravenous
immunoglobulin for 2% months. Her only current medication is prednisone. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Examination shows scattered petechiae and
multiple small ecchymoses over the upper and lower extremities. This patient should receive which of the following vaccines preoperatively?
Streptococcus Haemophilus influenzae Neisseria
pneumoniae Type b meningitidis

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
The spleen's major function involves immune response through both cell-mediated and humoral pathways. It removes opsonized pathogens and infected cells by mechanical filtration in the
sinusoids and through phagocytosis by splenic macrophages. Additionally, the spleen houses immunoglobulin-producing B lymphocytes. The spleen plays an important role in the clearance of
encapsulated pathogens such as Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, among others. Thus,
patients lacking a spleen are at increased risk for severe infection or sepsis with encapsulated bacteria. Up-to-date vaccinations against the encapsulated organisms S. pneumoniae, H.
influenzae, and N, meningitidis are indicated prior to splenectomy. Splenectomy patients may also require antibiotic prophylaxis at times, typically with penicillin or amoxicillin.
explanation.educational_objective:
Patients lacking a spleen are at increased risk for severe infection or sepsis with encapsulated bacteria. Up-to-date vaccinations against the encapsulated organisms
Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis are indicated prior to splenectomy.
oO Ce @ @ € 6 o

vignette.presentation:
2. Apreviously healthy 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He was kicked in the abdomen
while competing in a karate tournament. He initially reported only mild pain but now rates it as an 8 on a 10-point scale. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation that
is most severe in the epigastric region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
B} Gasirie-tteer

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Acute pancreatitis presents with epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back, along with nausea and emesis, often in a patient with a history of gallstones, alcohol use disorder, trauma,
hypertriglyceridemia, or hypercalcemia. Trauma to the epigastric area can cause acute pancreatitis, as seen in this patient. Acute pancreatitis can be complicated by necrosis, hemorrhage,
abscess, or the formation of pseudocysts. Laboratory studies often show increased serum amylase and lipase activity. Treatment of uncomplicated acute pancreatitis is largely supportive and
should include intravenous fluids, either normal saline or lactated Ringer solution, bowel rest, and pain control. Surgical intervention may be required in cases of complications.
explanation.educational_objective:
Acute pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back, along with nausea and emesis. It can occur in the setting of direct abdominal
trauma to the epigastric region. Laboratory studies often show increased serum amylase and lipase activity.

Exam Section 3: Item 3 of 50 National Board of Medical Examiners®
Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment

vignette.presentation:
3. A27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, delivers a healthy 334: '7-Ib 6-0z) newborn by cesarean delivery because of arrest of descent. Thirty-six hours later, she has chills, loss of
v f f f
appetite, and foul-smelling lochia. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a clean, dry
incision without erythema. There is no breast tenderness or erythema. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. The uterine fundus is tender to
palpation. Leukocyte count is 14,000/mm®. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
| A) Amtbiotetherapy

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.
"In 5 years, your risk for lung cancer will decrease to that of a nonsmoker."
"Your pulmonary function will not decrease further in the future."
"Your risk for myocardial infarction will be higher than that of a nonsmoker for the rest of your life, but your risk for cerebral infarction will decrease."

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Arecent postpartum patient with fever, leukocytosis, foul-smelling lochia, and uterine tenderness raises suspicion for endometritis, especially in the setting of prolonged rupture of membranes
(time from rupture of membranes to delivery). Postpartum endometritis is an acute, typically polymicrobial infection of the uterine endometrium involving a mixture of aerobes and anaerobes from
the genital tract. During labor and delivery, microbes from the genital tract can enter the uterine cavity and result in postpartum infection. Patients typically present with fever, severe tenderness of}
the uterine fundus, and mucopurulent vaginal discharge. Risk factors for endometritis include prelabor or prolonged rupture of membranes, prolonged labor, cesarean delivery, bacterial vaginosis,
Streptococcus (group B) colonization, and manual removal of the placenta. Treatment requires broad-spectrum antibiotics such as clindamycin and gentamicin for appropriate antimicrobial
coverage. Thus, the most appropriate next step for this patient is antibiotic therapy.
explanation.educational_objective:
Postpartum endometritis is a polymicrobial infection that presents with fever, uterine tenderness, and mucopurulent vaginal discharge. Risk factors include prelabor or
prolonged rupture of membranes, prolonged labor, cesarean delivery, bacterial vaginosis, Streptococcus (group B) colonization, and manual removal of the placenta. Treatment is with
intravenous antibiotics.

Exam Section 3: Item 4 of 50 National Board of Medical Examiners®
Comprehensive Clinical Science Self-Assessment
Yaa 37-year-old man comes to the physician for an examination required by his employer. He feels well. He has no known allergies or history of serious illness. He
takes no medications. He has smoked one and one-half packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks six beers weekly. He has a sedentary lifestyle. He is
178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 Ib); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His pulse is 68/min and regular, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to
auscultation; there is a prolonged expiratory phase. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. During the examination, the patient asks what he can expect if he
quits smoking now. Which of the following is the most appropriate physician response?
B) "In 5 years, your risk for lung cancer will decrease to that of a nonsmoker."
C) "Your pulmonary function will not decrease further in the future."
5) “Yourriskfortung-eance wl be the same-asitis now!
E) "Your risk for myocardial infarction will be higher than that of a nonsmoker for the rest of your life, but your risk for cerebral infarction will decrease."
Correct Answer: A.
Healthy patients who do not smoke experience age-related decline in pulmonary function starting at around age 25 years. For example, the lung parenchyma typically loses
its scaffolding, leading to dilation of air spaces, known as senile emphysema. Alveolar dead space also increases. Smoking increases the rate of age-related decline.
Smoking cessation is the most likely intervention to prevent worsening of this patient's obstructive lung disease. Long-term smokers are at risk of numerous diseases of the
lung including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is diagnosed by spirometry. This patient, with a prolonged expiratory phase, may have smoking- and age-
related lung decline or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Further diagnostic testing is needed to determine the diagnosis. Other common symptoms include dyspnea
on exertion and productive cough. Treatment focuses on preventing further decline in respiratory function through smoking cessation in addition to the use of medications,
such as inhaled antimuscarinics, short and long-acting B-adrenergic agonists, and corticosteroids. Patients with resting or ambulatory saturation less than 88% are also
candidates for oxygen therapy.
Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E.
"In 5 years, your risk for lung cancer will decrease to that of a nonsmoker" (Choice B) and "Your risk for lung cancer will be the same as it is now" (Choice D) are inaccurate.
The patient's lung cancer risk will remain increased compared to the general population because of his smoking history. However, his future risk will decrease if he quits
smoking compared to if he continues smoking.
“Your pulmonary function will not decrease further in the future" (Choice C) is inaccurate. Age-related pulmonary function decline typically begins around age 25 years.
Dilation of air spaces and increased alveolar space commonly occur with age.
“Your risk for myocardial infarction will be higher than that of a nonsmoker for the rest of your life, but your risk for cerebral infarction will decrease" (Choice E) accurately
describes the patient's myocardial infarction risk but not his cerebral infarction risk. Smoking history increases cerebral infarction risk. Smoking increases risk of
atherosclerotic buildup in both the coronary and intracranial arteries.
Educational Objective: In normal aging, air spaces dilate and alveolar dead space increases. Smokers should be encouraged to stop smoking as this intervention is the
most likely to prevent an increased rate of age-related pulmonary decline.

vignette.presentation:
5. A38-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of several red, painless lesions on her chest and abdomen that she first noticed 4 months ago. Medical history is remarkable only for occasional headaches, which she
describes as generally right sided and throbbing, with associated nausea and photophobia. Ibuprofen partially relieves the pain. She also takes an oral contraceptive. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active
with one male partner and they do not use condoms. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and she drinks one beer daily. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination discloses several small (3 to 5-
mm), slightly raised, erythematous lesions on her chest and abdomen as shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
No diagnostic studies are required to diagnose cherry angiomas. Cherry angiomas are common, benign, vascular lesions that may appear in patients after age 30 years. Patients often note an increase in the number of cherry angiomas as
they age. Clinically, cherry angiomas are characteristically small, round, bright red, dome-shaped papules found on the scalp, trunk, and extremities. Histologic examination of cherry angiomas shows congested, dilated capillaries and venules
within the superficial dermis. Patients may desire removal of individual lesions for cosmetic reasons or due to irritation; however, in general, no treatment is indicated. Patients who develop these growths should be provided reassurance by
the physician.
explanation.educational_objective:
Cherry angiomas are common, benign, vascular growths that patients may develop around age 30 years and often increase over time, Cherry angiomas are small, round, bright red papules found over the scalp, trunk,
and extremities. Cherry angiomas may be clinically monitored, and patients should be provided reassurance by the physician.

6. AeA. Id to the office b f a 4- ith hist of moderately painful ejaculation duri I inte On ionally, hi the ejaculate is dark and foul Ati
He also has had low back pain and mild lower pelvic pain for 8 weeks. During the past 6 months, he has been sexually active with four women; they use condoms inconsistently. He says he
has paid for sex and has had unprotected anal sex during this time. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a circumcised penis with no lesions. The testes and
epididymis are normal. The prostate is mildly tender to palpation and minimally enlarged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Placement of a urinary catheter to obtain urine for urinalysis and culture

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents with symptoms of recurrent urinary tract infection, pelvic or lower abdominal pain, dysuria or painful ejaculation; obstructive symptoms such as urinary frequency,
urgency, or difficulty voiding; and sexual symptoms such as bloody or discolored ejaculate, decreased libido, or erectile dysfunction. In contrast to acute bacterial prostatitis, patients are less likely to
present with fever. Patients may be asymptomatic between recurrent flares of symptoms. The most common risk factors include multiple sexual partners, unprotected anal sex, and the presence of
concomitant sexually transmitted infections. The diagnosis is most commonly established with the two-glass test, in which a urine sample is collected before and after prostatic massage and used for
cultures and microscopy. A ten-fold increase in bacterial concentration following prostatic massage localizes the infection to the prostate and is considered diagnostic. This is helpful to distinguish
prostatic infection from other urinary tract infections such as urethritis or cystitis. Fluoroquinolone antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment, although recurrences are common. Curative outcomes are
more frequent in antibiotic-naive patients and less frequent in patients with prostatic calculi.
explanation.educational_objective:
Chronic bacterial prostatitis presents with symptoms of recurrent urinary tract infection, pelvic or lower abdominal pain, dysuria or painful ejaculation, obstructive symptoms, and
symptoms of sexual dysfunction. Risk factors include multiple sexual partners, unprotected anal sex, and concomitant sexually transmitted infections. The diagnosis is established with urinary cultures
obtained before and after prostatic massage resulting in a ten-fold increase in bacterial concentration. Treatment is with fluoroquinolone antibiotics, although recurrences are common.

vignette.presentation:
7. A76-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit because of a 12-hour history of moderate chest pain and progressive shortness of breath. He has no history of serious illness and
takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 84/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 10 L/min of oxygen by
nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows jugular venous distention to the angle of the jaw bilaterally. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard
bilaterally. Administration of 100% oxygen by face mask is begun. His blood pressure is 78/42 mm Hg. Echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 10%. ECG shows evidence of an
anterior myocardial infarction. Administration of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
——B) Dobutamine
G}-Isepreterenet

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient, with recent anterior myocardial infarction, hypotension, chest pain, respiratory distress, hypoxia, jugular venous distension, and pulmonary edema is most likely in cardiogenic shock.
First-line therapy for cardiogenic shock includes inotropic support with dobutamine or dopamine. Dobutamine is a primarily B;-adrenergic agonist that stimulates inotropic and chronotropic activity,
resulting in increased cardiac contractility, stroke volume, heart rate, and cardiac output. It also possesses modest a4-adrenergic agonist activity, resulting in increased peripheral vascular contractility
that is useful to raise mean arterial pressure. Catecholamines, particularly norepinephrine, may also be used in conjunction with dobutamine. While norepinephrine as monotherapy or in conjunction
with dobutamine may be used for the treatment of cardiogenic shock in current practice, dobutamine remains the most frequently used agent of choice, though often, these agents are used in
combination.
explanation.educational_objective:
Cardiogenic shock presents with hypotension and evidence of end-organ damage in patients with acute decompensated heart failure. First-line therapy includes inotropic
support with dobutamine or dopamine. Norepinephrine may be used in conjunction with inotropic agents.

vignette.presentation:
8. Apreviously healthy 22-year-old woman comes to the physician 12 hours after the onset of swelling of her left arm. She lifts weights five times weekly and has been
focusing on strengthening her upper body during the past 2 weeks. Examination shows prominent superficial veins over the anterior left shoulder and chest. The left upper
extremity is edematous from the shoulder to the hand. There is a bluish discoloration of the left forearm and hand. Muscle strength and sensation are intact in all
extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the edema?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient with unilateral upper extremity swelling has a presentation consistent with a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). DVTs are common in the lower extremity, but
development of a spontaneous upper extremity DVT is rare. This classically presents in healthy young athletic individuals after vigorous upper extremity activity (eg, upper body
weight training). It is typically associated with anatomical abnormalities of the thoracic outlet that lead to compression and damage to the axillary and subclavian vein with
repetitive upper extremity use. Patients classically present with arm, shoulder, or neck pain and arm swelling. There may be associated dilation of the superficial collateral veins
over the upper arm and chest (Urschel sign). Diagnosis is made with Doppler ultrasonography showing a noncompressible vessel, and the intravascular thrombus is often shown.
Initial treatment is with anticoagulation.
explanation.educational_objective:
Isolated spontaneous upper extremity deep venous thrombosis is rare. Patients are typically young and healthy, and present with upper extremity pain and
swelling following vigorous upper extremity activity. Diagnosis is made with Doppler ultrasonography, and initial treatment is with anticoagulation.

vignette.presentation:
9. Apreviously healthy 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of noisy breathing, runny nose, and cough. Her mother says the patient has had decreased oral
intake during the past 4 hours with increasingly severe cough and noisy breathing. She has not had drooling or change in the pitch or intensity of her cry. She does not appear to be cyanotic.
Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. She can fully open her mouth. The uvula is midline, and the tonsils are mildly
erythematous, symmetric, and moderately enlarged bilaterally. Examination shows intercostal and suprasternal retractions, inspiratory stridor, and nasal flaring. There are no crackles or
expiratory wheezing. A chest x-ray shows a "shaggy" tracheal air column and peribronchial cuffing with no parenchymal densities; there is no cardiomegaly. Her symptoms show no
improvement after two administrations of nebulized racemic epinephrine or with sitting upright. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Bacterial tracheitis is a potentially serious respiratory infection of the trachea commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, or Staphylococcus aureus. Bacterial infection
of the trachea leads to inflammation and results in difficulty breathing, cough, and hoarseness. Typical clinical presentation includes severe cough, difficulty breathing with rapid respiratory rate and
intercostal retractions, stridor, and fever. Physical examination will show inspiratory stridor but generally clear lung sounds. Chest x-ray may show peribronchial cuffing and a tracheal air column with
irregular borders. Diagnosis of bacterial tracheitis can be made clinically. Prompt diagnosis is paramount to slow and reverse the course of respiratory compromise. Antibiotics are the treatment of
choice for bacterial tracheitis, along with corticosteroids. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required for severe cases. Patients are often hospitalized for monitoring.
explanation.educational_objective:
Bacterial tracheitis is a potentially serious upper respiratory infection of the trachea. Patients will typically present with cough, increased work of breathing, stridor, and fever.
Additionally, chest x-ray may show a tracheal air column with irregular borders. Lungs are generally clear on auscultation. Treatment requires antibiotics, corticosteroids, and often hospitalization.

vignette.presentation:
37. Id ith cystic fibrosis is admitted to the critical it be f hi jis and pull fail During the t 4 he has been hospitalized nine ti fe
treatment of pulmonary failure and intestinal obstructions caused by meconium ileus equivalent; 1 month ago, she was in the critical care unit for 2 weeks because of worsening lung function.
She repeatedly has refused to be considered for lung transplant. She has a living will that states her wish for no cardiopulmonary resuscitation if she undergoes cardiac arrest while
hospitalized. Psychologic testing during the past year has confirmed that she is mentally competent. She is heavily sedated, intubated, and mechanically ventilated. Her pulmonary failure
worsens, and her family asks whether extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) treatment could be used to improve her condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate
physician response?
A} EGMO+is-contraindieated beeause-ofthe-patient's history of hemoptysis

choices.text: The family should not be initiating the patient's medical treatment plans

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in the CFTR gene, which leads to a deficiency in a chloride channel that secretes chloride in the lungs and gastrointestinal
tract and reabsorbs chloride in sweat glands. This abnormal chloride transport causes decreased chloride and water secretion, increased water reabsorption, and abnormally viscous mucus in the
lungs and gastrointestinal tract. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) treatment involves prolonged mechanical cardiopulmonary support by circulating blood outside of the body and
subjecting it to gas exchange until respiratory and hemodynamic parameters are met. ECMO is typically used for acute and reversible causes of cardiac or respiratory failure. Contraindications include
conditions interfering with recovery, a poor prognosis from the primary condition, and uncontrollable bleeding. CF is a chronic, progressive disorder, and increasing respiratory dysfunction is a common|
cause of death. While ECMO provides respiratory support temporarily, it is not reasonable to continue indefinitely once a CF patient's lungs have ceased to function. Some CF patients use ECMO to
temporarily bridge them to lung transplant; however, this patient is not considering lung transplant.
explanation.educational_objective: When a patient is incapacitated, the physician should seek substituted judgment about medical decisions from living wills, advance directives, or legal

vignette.presentation:
11. A42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, decreased appetite, and mild swelling of her arms and legs. Twenty years ago, she underwent
transplantation of a donor kidney from her sister for treatment of polycystic kidney disease. She has been compliant with her immunosuppressive therapy. Medications include prednisone and
azathioprine. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 170/98 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor. Abdominal examination shows no
tenderness or enlargement of the transplanted kidney. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL, serum urea nitrogen concentration is 50 mg/dL, and serum creatinine concentration is 5.3
mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's impending renal failure?
A} Aeute-cellular rejection

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Chronic, progressive transplant dysfunction manifests as chronic transplant nephropathy in the transplanted kidney. Chronic rejection, which occurs over months to years following transplantation, is
secondary to a CD4+ T lymphocyte response against donor peptides such as major histocompatibility complexes (MHC). Resultant T lymphocyte activation leads to cytokine production and both
humoral and cellular hypersensitivity reactions (type II and IV, respectively). These reactions result in vascular arteriosclerosis and smooth muscle proliferation with subsequent parenchymal fibrosis
and atrophy of the transplanted organ. Diagnostic workup includes serum and urine laboratory evaluation of kidney function as well as kidney ultrasonography and biopsy, which will show the findings
described. Other examples of chronic transplant rejection include vanishing bile duct syndrome of the liver, bronchiolitis obliterans of the lung, and rapid atherosclerosis of the heart.
Immunosuppressive medical therapy does not adequately prevent chronic rejection. It is associated with increased morbidity and mortality secondary to organ failure. It may require reinitiating kidney
replacement therapy (eg, dialysis), or another organ transplant.
explanation.educational_objective:
Chronic transplant nephropathy, which occurs months to years following transplantation, is secondary to a CD4+ T lymphocyte response against donor peptides such as major
histocompatibility complexes. This results in vascular arteriosclerosis and smooth muscle proliferation with subsequent parenchymal fibrosis and atrophy of the transplanted organ.
Immunosuppressive medical therapy does not adequately prevent chronic rejection. It may require reinitiation of kidney replacement therapy (eg, dialysis), or another organ transplant.

vignette.presentation:
12. Apreviously healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of nausea and vomiting for the past 36 hours. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There is tenderness to
palpation of the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 5800/mm3
Serum
Bilirubin
Total 11 mg/dL
Direct 2.2 mg/dL
AST 1095 U/L
ALT 1300 U/L
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient, who presents with findings of jaundice, direct and indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and increased serum liver enzyme concentrations, most likely has hepatitis. Causes of acute hepatitis include viral infections, alcohol, medications,
autoimmune disease, and ischemic injury, among others. Common symptoms during acute hepatitis can include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, pruritus, and abdominal distension. Serologic testing for acute
viral hepatitis includes anti-hepatitis A virus immunoglobulin M (IgM) and immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies, anti-hepatitis C virus IgM and IgG antibodies, and more specific evaluation of multiple anti-hepatitis B virus (HBV) antibodies and
antigens due to the propensity of HBV to cause chronic and subacute infections. Other viruses commonly implicated in cases of viral hepatitis include herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and varicella
zoster virus. Management of acute hepatitis includes supportive care and treatment of complications that may arise, such as metabolic abnormalities and hepatic encephalopathy. More specific treatments can be pursued once the underlying
cause has been identified. This patient's acute increase in liver enzymes in the absence of leukocytosis likely indicates acute viral hepatitis.
explanation.educational_objective:
Acute viral hepatitis presents with fatigue, nausea, vomiting, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, pruritus, and abdominal distension. Laboratory studies will typically show large acute increases in ALT and AST. Viruses
often implicated include hepatitis A virus, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, varicella zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and herpes simplex virus type 1 and

vignette.presentation:
13. A9-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has a 5-month history of intermittent moderate right flank pain that radiates to the back. The pain occurs two to three times monthly and lasts.
2 to 3 days before resolving spontaneously. She has not had fever, vomiting, diarrhea, pain with urination, or urinary frequency. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Multiple urine cultures
during the past 5 months have been negative. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is right costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show:
Serum creatinine 4.3 mgidL
Urine
pH 6.0
Specific gravity 1.010
Blood trace
Protein none
WBC O/hpf
Nitrites none
Abdominal ultrasonography shows absence of the left kidney and severe dilation of the right renal pelvis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to prevent progression of this patient's renal failure?

choices.text: Perform cystoscopy with bladder outlet dilatation
Gall the patient's mother to encourage her to support the patient's treatment plan-at home
Demonstrate a new mobile application on cellular telephones that aids regular monitoring of blood glucose concentration
Use humor to diffuse the situation and create a better physician-patient relationship

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Congenital urinary tract abnormalities include, but are not limited to, unilateral kidney agenesis (absence of one kidney), fused kidneys, ureteral stricture and stenosis, duplex collecting system, posterior urethral valves,
bladder agenesis, bladder exstrophy, hypo- or epispadias, and urethral strictures. In cases of unilateral kidney agenesis, care must be taken to preserve the function of an otherwise single remaining kidney. Regardless of the
cause of malformation, ureteral obstruction and vesicoureteral reflux are common complications. Chronic reflux causes hydroureter and hydronephrosis, with compression atrophy (reflux nephropathy) of the renal parenchyma,
as shown in this patient's history and ultrasonography findings. This can lead to kidney failure. Insertion of a percutaneous nephrostomy tube can be helpful as a temporary measure to prevent progression of kidney failure
prior to definitive management of the vesicoureteral reflux or ureteral obstruction.
explanation.educational_objective:
Ureteral obstruction and vesicoureteral reflux are common complications of congenital urinary tract abnormalities. Insertion of a percutaneous nephrostomy tube can be helpful as a temporary measure
to prevent progression of kidney failure prior to definitive management of the vesicoureteral reflux or ureteral obstruction.

vignette.presentation:
15. A62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of tingling in his left hand radiating to the ring and small fingers. He has not had any recent trauma or weakness in his
hand. He has end-stage renal disease secondary to hypertension. He has been receiving hemodialysis for the past 3 months. He also has coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus,
congestive heart failure, and gout. Current medications are metoprolol, lisinopril, clonidine, insulin glargine, allopurinol, and 81-mg aspirin. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 70/min,
and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border. There is a dialysis fistula in place in the left upper
arm; there is no inflammation, but a thrill is palpated. Physical examination shows no edema of the upper and lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows decreased sensation to light
touch over the medial aspect of the left hand, ring and small fingers, and the medial aspect of the left arm to the elbow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Peripheral nerves, particularly in areas that are not protected by surrounding soft tissue, are vulnerable to injury or compression. The ulnar nerve is vulnerable to compression at the elbow, or less
commonly, the wrist. Common causes of ulnar nerve compression are elbow trauma, compression or traction from leaning on the elbow or repeated elbow flexion, or elbow joint pathology (eg,
osteophytes). Patients with arteriovenous fistulas placed at the elbow commonly experience ulnar nerve compression. Patients typically present with numbness and paresthesias in the ring and small
fingers. Patients with ulnar nerve compression at the wrist may also present with hand weakness and atrophy. Electrodiagnostic testing confirms the diagnosis. Treatment typically starts with behavior
modification and ergonomic improvements. Decompressive surgery is indicated for severe or refractory cases.
explanation.educational_objective:
Ulnar nerve compression is a common complication of hemodialysis catheterization. Patients with ulnar nerve compression at the elbow typically present with numbness and
paresthesias in the ring and small fingers. Treatment typically starts with behavior modification and ergonomic improvements. Decompressive surgery is indicated for severe or refractory cases.

vignette.presentation:
18. A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of shortness of breath and cough, which have progressed to severe respiratory distress. He has a
history of intravenous illicit drug use. He lives in a homeless shelter. On arrival, he is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Examination shows coarse breath sounds bilaterally. Respiratory
therapy is begun. Two days later, cultures of blood and sputum grow Neisseria meningitidis. Which of the following is the most appropriate measure to prevent the spread of this patient's
disease to hospital personnel?

choices.text: Prophylaxis for all personnel working in the emergency department when the patient arrived
No prophylaxis is indicated for hospital personnel

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Bacterial meningitis presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status, typically following a prodrome of upper respiratory tract infection symptoms. Neisseria meningitidis is one
of the most common pathogens to cause meningitis in adults. A risk factor for N. meningitidis meningitis, also known as meningococcal disease, is communal living (eg, homeless shelters). Empiric
treatment involves third generation cephalosporins. Management should also include chemoprophylaxis for close contacts. Close contacts are typically defined as individuals who have been in close
proximity (within feet) of the patient for a prolonged time (more than 8 hours) or who have been directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions. Preferred prophylactic agents include rifampin,
ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.
explanation.educational_objective:
Meningococcal disease commonly spreads among close contacts of infected patients, particularly in communal living spaces. Prophylaxis for close contacts, typically defined as}
individuals who have been in close proximity (within feet) of the patient for a prolonged time (more than 8 hours) or who have been directly exposed to the patient's oral secretions, is the most
appropriate measure to limit the spread of this patient's disease. Preferred prophylactic agents include rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.

19. A‘57-year-old man comes to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of severe shortness of breath. He has not had any other symptoms. He has long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and hydrochlorothiazide. He has never smoked. He is employed as a truck driver. His
temperature is 37.4°C (98.4°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hig. Pulse oximetry on room alr shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Faint wheezes are heard on the left. There is an S,. Examination of the lower extremities shows 1+ edema bilaterally. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Arterial blood gas,
analysis on room air shows:
pH 7.44
Peo, 33 mmHg
Po, = 82mmHg
chest x-ray is shown. Which ofthe folowing is the most appropriate next step in management?
‘A) Measurement of cardiac enzyme activites

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patent's presentation and findings are consistent with acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Acute PE classically presents with acute chest pain, shortness of breath, and hypoxemia. Some patients may also experience unexplained syncope. The classic presentation of acute PE i infrequently present. Iti often dificult to distinguish PE from other acute
respiratory, cardiac, and systemic disorders on a clinical basis. The dferentil includes but sno limited to pneumonia, lung infarction, asthma exacerbation, pulmonary hypertension, pericardial tamponade, acute coronary syndrome, panic episode, and the many causes of syncope, if present. The physician must maintain a high index of suspicion, and the use
clinical decision aids, such as Wells score, is recommended. Risk factors for acute PE include immobility (truck driving in the case of this patient), obesity, recent surgery, malignancy, pregnancy, use of oral contraceptives, trauma, fracture of long bones, and inherited thrombophilia. ECG often shows normal sinus rhythm or sinus tachycardia and is generally
Nonspecific. Arterial blood gas analysis may show acute respiratory alkalosis, hypoxemia, and an increased Alveolar-arteral gradient because of vertilaion-pertusion mismatch. Sprral CT scan of the chests the preferred method to confirm diagnosis.
explanation.educational_objective:
Acute pulmonary embolism typically presents with acute chest pain, shortness of breath, and hypoxemia. However, vague and nonspecific presentations are common. Sudden onset shortness of breath, especially in the setting of risk factors such as immobility, obesity, recent surgery, malignancy, pregnancy, use of oral contraceptives,
trauma, fracture of long bones, and inherited thrombophilia should prompt rapid diagnostic testing for a potentially life-threatening pulmonary embolism. Spiral CT scan of the chest is the preferred method to confirm diagnosis.

vignette.presentation:
20. An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of progressive abdominal distention and lethargy. His family reports that he has not been awake or fully alert for 4 hours. The patient has
hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications are atorvastatin, metoprolol, finasteride, and a daily aspirin. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood
pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by nonrebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient opens his eyes and moves his extremities in response to painful stimuli. Abdominal
examination shows distention over the lower quadrants, dullness to percussion to the level of the umbilicus, and an enlarged multinodular prostate. Bladder catheterization yields 1700 mL of turbid urine.
Piperacillin-tazobactam, large-volume crystalloid, and norepinephrine therapy are begun. Two hours later, the patient produces 75 mL/h of clear urine but remains lethargic. His blood pressure is 90/65 mm Hg. Laboratory studies
show:
Hemoglobin 12 gidL.
Hematocrit 36%
Leukocyte count 22,000/mm3
Serum
Nat 125 mEqiL
Kr 5 mEq/L
cl 93 mEq/L.
HCO,- 22 mEq/L.
Urea nitrogen 35 mg/dL.
Glucose 75 mg/dL.
Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's persistent hypotension?

choices.text: Bladder irrigation with amphotericin B solution

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Intravenous administration of hydrocortisone is the most appropriate next step in management. This patient presents with altered mental status, urinary retention, and evidence of a urinary tract infection and sepsis with hypotension that is not
responding to fluid resuscitation, antibiotics, or first-line vasopressor therapy. Results of laboratory studies showing hyponatremia, hypochloremia, borderline hyperkalemia, and increased urea nitrogen and creatinine are all suggestive of
concomitant adrenal insufficiency. The cause of this patient's adrenal insufficiency may be related to hypoperfusion of the gland and limited production of hormones, or it may represent the relative adrenal insufficiency and limited response to
existing hormones that characterizes a case of sepsis. There is disagreement around the pathophysiology and clinical utility of relative adrenal insufficiency, however, this patient has refractory hypotension and consistent electrolyte and acid-
base disturbances, a presentation appropriately characterized as adrenal insufficiency regardless of the underlying cause. In this setting, supplementation with intravenous administration of glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, is the most
appropriate next step. Limited responsiveness to vasopressor medications in sepsis is a hallmark of endocrine contributions to shock.
explanation.educational_objective:
Acute adrenal insufficiency can occur from insufficient production of or responsiveness to adrenal hormones. This should be suspected when there is persistent hypotension in a patient who has received large volume
intravenous fluids and vasopressors. Administration of intravenous glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, is the most appropriate

vignette.presentation:
21. A22-year-old male college student comes to the clinic because of a 3-month history of fatigue, persistent cough, chronic malaise, occasional night sweats, and a 7-kg (15-Ib) weight loss
despite no change in appetite. He says he has felt stressed at school and that his grades have been declining. He had infectious mononucleosis 5 years ago. He takes no medications. He
appears tired. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 Ib); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Pulse is 98/min and regular, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg.
Cardiopulmonary examination discloses wheezing at both bases and distant heart sounds. Abdomen is soft with no tenderness; liver edge is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin.
Large, matted lymph nodes are palpated bilaterally in the supraclavicular area, axilla, and groin. Examination of a biopsy specimen of a superficial inguinal lymph node confirms the presence
of Reed-Sternberg cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Hodgkin disease is a type of lymphoma, predominantly B-cell in origin, that occurs most commonly in patients aged 20 to 30 and 55 to 65 years. Patients typically present with lymphadenopathy or a
dominant lymph node mass along with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss (ie, B symptoms), malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, and pruritus. Occasionally, patients may
develop Pel-Ebstein fever, which is characterized by recurrent high fevers for 1 to 2 weeks followed by 1- to 2-week afebrile periods. A specific sign for Hodgkin disease-associated lymphadenopathy
is alcohol-induced pain at the enlarged lymph node sites. The most common sites for lymphadenopathy are the neck and mediastinum. Definitive diagnosis requires core needle or excisional lymph
node biopsy showing Reed-Sternberg cells, as in this patient. This is followed by either CT scan with contrast or PET scan to identify the extent of disease. Hodgkin disease is staged differently than
other lymphomas and typically has a favorable prognosis. Laboratory markers that are often increased in patients with Hodgkin disease include markers of cell turnover such as lactate dehydrogenase|
and inflammatory markers such as ESR. Chemotherapy with concurrent radiation therapy depending on the location and bulkiness of the disease is often curative.
explanation.educational_objective:
Hodgkin lymphoma is a B-cell malignancy that presents as lymphadenopathy or a dominant lymph node mass. B symptoms and hepatosplenomegaly may be present.
Diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on core needle or excisional lymph node biopsy. CT scan with contrast or PET scan are used to evaluate the extent of disease.
Chemotherapy with concurrent radiation therapy depending on the location and bulkiness of disease is often curative.
a C e @ © © m

vignette.presentation:
22. A67-year-old man comes to the emergency department 20 minutes after the sudden onset of substernal chest pain. He has not had shortness of breath. He has hypertension and
hyperlipidemia. His medications are enalapril and simvastatin. On arrival, he appears pale and anxious. His pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 88/64 mm Hg.
Central venous pressure is estimated to be 6 cm H,O (N=5-8). The point of maximal impulse is laterally displaced. The lungs are clear to auscultation. With the patient in the supine position,
a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. S, and S, are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show an
increased troponin T concentration. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF and in leads V 4p to Vex. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in
management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
This patient with substernal chest pain, increased troponin, and ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF and in leads V4p to Ver has a presentation consistent with an inferior ST-elevation
myocardial infarction (STEMI) with associated right ventricular infarction. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) encompasses a spectrum of disease, including unstable angina, non-ST-elevation
myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), and STEMI. ACS classically presents with acute-onset chest pain, often radiating to the neck, jaw, or arm, along with shortness of breath, nausea, and light-
headedness. Risk factors include a history of smoking, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. Diagnosis is made using clinical history, analysis of cardiac biomarkers (will be
increased in both STEMI and NSTEMI, but normal in unstable angina) and an ECG that may show ST-segment elevation or depression, inverted T-waves, or Q-waves in a particular vascular
distribution of the heart. This patient has an inferior myocardial infarction evidenced by the ST-segment elevation in leads II, Ill, and aVF, and right ventricular infarction as evidenced by the ST
elevation in V4p to Ver. Patients with right ventricular infarcts often present in cardiogenic shock resulting from the acute dysfunction of the right ventricle. These patients are preload-dependent and
should be given intravenous crystalloids (eg, saline) as a part of their initial stabilization. Treatment of patients with STEMI requires the administration of antiplatelet agents (eg, aspirin, clopidogrel),
anticoagulants (eg, heparin), pain medications, and ultimately coronary revascularization. In cases of a STEMI, the patient should undergo revascularization as soon as possible.
explanation.educational_objective:
ST-elevation myocardial infarction is a true emergency that classically presents with exertional substernal chest pressure, dyspnea, diaphoresis, and nausea in a patient with
risk factors. Troponin will be increased, and ECG will show ST-segment elevation in a specific vascular distribution. Definitive treatment is coronary revascularization. Right ventricular infarctions can
lead to cardiogenic shock; these patients are preload-dependent and should be given intravenous crystalloids (eg, saline) as a part of their initial stabilization.

vignette.presentation:
23. A 22-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, aborta 1, at 9 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician because of mild vaginal bleeding for 2 days. Her first pregnancy ended in spontaneous

abortion at 6 weeks’ gestation. She received Rh,(D) immune globulin at that time. Three years ago, she underwent multiple operative repairs of injuries sustained in a motor vehicle collision

and received transfusion of packed red blood cells perioperatively. She has no other history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Examination shows a uterus

consistent in size with a 9-week gestation. There is scant blood coming from the closed cervical os. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows a viable singleton intrauterine pregnancy. Routine

prenatal laboratory studies are performed and Rh,(D) immune globulin is administered. Her blood group is B, Rh-negative. She is positive for the Kell antibody with a titer of 1:16. Which of

the following is the strongest predisposing risk factor for isoimmunization to the Kell erythrocyte antibody in this patient?

choices.text: Previous administration of Rh(D) immune globulin

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
A mother can develop antibodies against red blood cell (RBC) antigens after being exposed to fetal blood antigens during delivery or from a previous blood transfusion. The likelihood of
isoimmunization is directly related to the amount of blood to which the patient is exposed. Thus, in this case, this patient likely developed antibodies to the Kell RBC antigen after being exposed to it in
her blood transfusion. Additionally, blood transfusions are not typically screened for Kell antigens in the United States. Because maternal antibodies can cross the placenta, it is important to determine
whether this patient's fetus has Kell-positive or Kell-negative RBCs. If her fetus had Kell-positive RBCs, the antibodies created by her immune system would cause hemolysis of the fetal erythrocytes,
leading to severe fetal hemolytic anemia (eg, erythroblastosis fetalis) and likely fetal demise. As the mother has no signs of hemolysis in the presence of anti-Kell antibodies, her RBCs do not have
Kell antigens, and she would not have contributed a Kell antigen to her fetus. The easiest way to determine the antigen status of the fetus is to determine the antigen status of the father. If he is Kell
negative as well, then the fetus will be Kell negative, and there is no risk of erythroblastosis fetalis. However, if he is positive, there is a possibility that the fetus will be Kell-antigen positive and suffer
from erythroblastosis fetalis.
explanation.educational_objective:
Women can develop antibodies against red blood cell antigens after a blood transfusion or being exposed to fetal blood antigens during delivery. The likelihood of
isoimmunization is directly related to the amount of blood to which the patient is exposed. While Rh(D) is the most common alloimmunization, maternal antibodies can also form to minor antigens,
such as Kell. Alloimmunization puts the fetus at risk of hemolytic anemia, erythroblastosis fetalis, and death.

vignette.presentation:
24. A92-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after a neighbor found him lethargic in his home. The neighbor reports that the patient has no living relatives, so she visits him regularly. On
admission, he is agitated, belligerent, and confused and says that he sees angels and demons. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood
pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung bases. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 20 mg/dL and creatinine concentration
of 1.3 mg/dL. Treatment with antibiotic therapy is begun for pneumonia and a urinary tract infection. Four hours later, he pulls out his nasogastric tube and intravenous and urinary catheters.
Three days later, mental status examination shows no evidence of visual hallucinations. He recalls zero of three items after 5 minutes. The most appropriate next step in discharge planning is
to contact which of the following within the hospital?

choices.text: Bioethics department to discuss futile medical treatment
Palliative care services to discuss end-of-life planning

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
There are a lot of factors to consider when approaching the decision of safely discharging a patient. In this situation, this patient has no living relatives and is checked on by his neighbor regularly. He
was found to have pneumonia and a urinary tract infection, which luckily had not yet progressed to sepsis. However, this raises concerns about whether the patient is able to care for himself. After
sufficient treatment of his pneumonia and urinary tract infection, the patient is no longer showing evidence of hallucinations. At this point, it is appropriate to assess the patient's mental status to
evaluate his capacity and ability to take care of himself. Since he was then unable to recall any items after 5 minutes, this should raise concern that the patient has significant cognitive deficits and
would not likely be safe to live at home on his own. Because of this, involving social services at this time to arrange placement in a supervised living facility is the most appropriate next step. The
safety of the patient should always be first and foremost when discussing a discharge plan.
explanation.educational_objective:
Safe discharge planning should be a first and foremost concern for positions of medical staff. Patients who are unable to care for themselves, particularly those who do not have
family involvement or help, will likely necessitate the assistance of social services to identify a safe discharge location and plan. The involvement of social services early in the clinical course is helpful
in establishing an optimum discharge plan.

vignette.presentation:
25. AG67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of episodes of vision loss in her left eye. She has had three episodes during this time; each episode lasted 5 minutes and resolved spontaneously. She has a 10-year history of

hypertension, a 2-year history of worsening arthritis, and mitral valve prolapse. Her medications are lisinopril and ibuprofen. Her blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. A photograph of the left fundus is shown. On cardiac examination, a midsystolic click and a

grade 2/6, late systolic murmur are heard best over the apex. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
‘Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral, painless vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia as a result of microembolization of the ophthalmic artery. It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusion, which is considered an
ophthalmic stroke. This patient's fundus photograph is notable for several Hollenhorst plaques, which are yellow, refractile cholesterol emboli that may be found within retinal arterioles, often at arteriolar bifurcations. A history suggestive of amaurosis fugax or clinical
identification of a Hollenhorst plaque should prompt an emergent evaluation for sources of potential emboli, the majority of which originate from the carotid arteries. This patient's amaurosis fugax and history of hypertension are suggestive of an ulcerative plaque of the left
carotid artery. Evaluation should include prompt carotid duplex ultrasonography. Treatment of carotid vascular or cardiac valvular disease can prevent central retinal arterial occlusion, which may cause irreversible blindness and stroke.
explanation.educational_objective:
Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia caused by emboli. A Hollenhorst plaque is a yellow, refractile, cholesterol embolus that is visible within retinal arterioles. Patients who
present with amaurosis fugax or a Hollenhorst plaque should undergo an emergent evaluation with carotid duplex ultrasonography to evaluate for the definitive source, which is most commonly the ipsilateral carotid artery.

vignette.presentation:
26. A47-year-old man comes to the clinic because of of worsening dull pain “in my stomach” and generalized itching. He has had a decreased appetite resulting in an 11.3-kg (25-Ib)
weight loss; eating does not affect the pain. He ha: His last visit to a physician was more than 30 years ago. He takes no medications. He has smoked
one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He does not drink alcohol om (5 ft 10 /m?. Vital signs are within normal limits.
Abdominal examination shows fullness and mild tenderness to palpation over the epigastric region. Rectal examination shows no abnormi ; test of the stool for occult blood Is negative.
Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum studies show
Total bilirubin 6 mg/dL.
Alkaline phosphatase 140 U/L
AST 160 UIL
ALT 175 UIL
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
__B) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast,
CC) Flat and upright abdominal x-rays

choices.text: Ultrasonography of the abdominal right upper quadrant

explanation.correct_answer_explanation:
Pancreatic cancer is associated with a high mortality rate, as it commonly presents after becoming locally invasive or metastatic. It classically presents with fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and painless
jaundice. Physical examination may show hepatomegaly, cachexia, and a right upper quadrant or epigastric mass on palpation of the abdomen. Laboratory studies frequently show hyperbilirubinemia, as
seen in this patient, indicative of cholestasis secondary to compression by a pancreatic head carcinoma. For tumors arising in the body or tail of the pancreas, migratory superficial thrombophlebitis, as well
as arterial and venous emboli, can occur. Occasionally, pancreatic cancer is diagnosed as an incidental finding on an imaging study used in the evaluation of another pathology. Risk factors for its
development include smoking, obesity, chronic pancreatitis, and a family history or genetic predisposition, among others. Treatment is with surgical resection, which is the best curative option. Because of
this, a mass isolated to the pancreas is more likely to be resectable and thus associated with an improved prognosis. This patient likely has pancreatic cancer as he is presenting with painless
hyperbilirubinemia, unintentional weight loss, abdominal fullness, 30-year smoking history, as well as mild increases in alkaline phosphatase, ALT, and AST. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is the most
appropriate imaging to evaluate for suspected cases of pancreatic cancer.
explanation.educational_objective:
Pancreatic cancer classically presents with fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and painless jaundice. Laboratory studies frequently show hyperbilirubinemia indicative of cholestasis
secondary to compression by a pancreatic head carcinoma. Risk factors for its development include smoking, obesity, and a family history or genetic predisposition. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is
the initial imaging of choice when there is concern for underlying pancreatic cancer. Treatment is with surgical resection, which is the best curative option.
